snippet: Nearly 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915, during World War I. Turks by and large do not believe mass killings were planned.
abstract: World prepares to observe 100th anniversary of the Armenian genocide, in which some 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915; Turkish government has softened its denial of event in later years, but still maintains that atrocity was not committed systematically, contradicting broad consensus among historians; denial remains overwhelmingly common among country's population as well.

byline.contributor: Ceylan Yeginsu and Sebnem Arsu contributed reporting from Istanbul.

lead_paragraph: Nearly 1.5 million Armenians died at the hands of the Ottoman Empire in 1915, during World War I. Turks by and large do not believe mass killings were planned.

headline.main: A Century After Armenian Genocide, Turkey’s Denial Only Deepens
headline.print_headline: A Century After a Genocide, Turkey’s Denial Only Deepens

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
